body: BTW I think the Jenkins failure is a hardcoded port that is being allocated by two jobs running in parallel on the same box.

R: @amitsela @lukecwik

Hmm, the travis failure is kind of worrying. @manuzhang does Gearpump require Java 8? Beam is generally trying very hard to keep the core at Java 7.

That said, we can easily add an option to travis to disable Gearpump in Java 7 builds if this is required.

@kennknowles @dhalperi 
I'm afraid that line is not lost. Gearpump requires Java 8 so I put it in the profile.

```
    <profile>
      <id>java8</id>
      <activation>
        <jdk>[1.8,)</jdk>
      </activation>
      <modules>
        <module>gearpump</module>
      </modules>
    </profile>
```

Thank you.

R: @dhalperi Please review.
@kennknowles okay, let me try.
LGTM, but I will wait for Flinkers to LGTM before merging :)

@dhalperi Here is an initial stab at it. Few things to note,
- End-to-End tests pass. I have not verified that the dynamic splitting feature works on Dataflow yet. Wanted to get the code out for initial review. 
- I have covered most important test cases but there is definitely room for more coverage, but in another PR (in the interest of keeping this one small)
- Regarding the DatastoreFactory / QuerySplitter, I modified to be created lazily and made them transient to ensure that the Source is serailizable.
Right, of course. It is unfortunate that it fails to appear in Jenkins when it did run.
LGTM
@kennknowles How may I port this change to `gearpump-runner` branch since it conflicts now ? A further question is how frequently we keep branch sync to master.

I think https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/539 took care of most of the changes applied to the Spark runner here, so a rebase is in place.
As for `RunnableOnService` coverage:
- Streaming tests are definitely not covered for obvious reasons.
- IO tests are unique as well.
  I think the rest of the tests (that should keep running continuously) are covered by `RunnableOnService`. There are also tests such as `SerializationTest` and `SideEffectsTest` which I'm not sure are covered by `RunnableOnService` but also but sure they should be running constantly.
  @kennknowles for the Spark runner in Batch mode, is there anything else missing besides `Read.Bound` support in order for the runner to execute all Batch tests ? I have this worked in the Spark runner 2 branch and I'm thinking of backporting this into the runner's current version so if that would help, I'll do that.
Can also remove https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/runners/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/spark/SparkStreamingPipelineOptions.java#L40 in that case.

Generally makes sense, even more, most tests on runners will probably be `local` because of setup/teardown overhead and the cost of maintaining cluster/s for constant testing. Also, most functionality is OK to test this way, except for serialization maybe.
But having said that, doesn't it mean that Dataflow is the exception here ? AFAIK Spark, Flink and even Gearpump run tests on a local instance.
So unless I'm missing something, there should probably be a `cluster-runnable-on-service-tests` instead of (or in addition to) `local-runnable-on-service-tests`.
WDYT ?

Thanks for the PR @kennknowles! Could you shed some lights on the current testing configuration? As far as I understand, the following tests are configured for the Flink Runner:
- Unit tests
- Runnable on Service tests (activated by property) [batch]
- local Runnable on Service tests [streaming] (disabled by default)
- local Runnable on Service tests [batch] (disabled by default)

Is that correct?
Should we move the config for the streaming tests to the new profile as well? They are deactivated for now but they will be at some (near) point in the future.

> Should we move the config for the streaming tests to the new profile as well? They are deactivated for now but they will be at some (near) point in the future.

+1 would make sense

Hi @dhalperi,

I've added KinesisMockReadTest, which mocks kinesis and runs using directrunner and very similar integration test called KinesisReaderIT - this one uses the real kinesis.

Can you please take a look now?

Local testing is excellent for unit tests or "fast postcommits". But I think we want to make it easier and easier to test Beam on remote infra of all sorts -- this is our primary intended use case.

E.g., I'd like there to be a post-commit that runs on a permanent Flink cluster, a permanent Spark cluster, etc. These are the things we need to make sure work well!

R: @tgroh @dhalperi

Thomas implemented Create-as-bounded-source. Can you take a first look @tgroh ?
This seems like two changes - a file split, and updates to the source to support dynamic splits. Can you separate them into multiple commits?

Thanks @kennknowles @amitsela. Rebased from master. Only change is adding runtime dependencies to example/java to support Flink and Spark runner.

PTAL
Sure, let me do that

I am still not convinced that implementing dynamic rebalancing this way (oversplitting + grouping the bundles) is a better idea than simply oversplitting (which would require far fewer code to implement). Can you comment on that?

The idea is to not have too many sub-sources resulting from oversplits initially that runners might not be able to handle efficiently (additional RPCs back and forth to runner to request work items etc.). I don't know if we have any data supporting this but just intuition. @dhalperi might have more to add here. 

I don't think it is a lot of code, (this PR has a bunch of things not related to dynamic rebalancing, I am breaking it into relevant parts). Although I don't how much more complexity dynamic rebalancing adds in practice while running jobs in production.
LGTM. Thank you.
Thanks, LGTM.  Sorry for the delay.

Vikas is right. In general, oversplitting is considered harmful by runners. We still need to try to honor the runner's requested bundle size; we oversplit only to provide later resharding of the bundles.
R: @silviulica
@dhalperi A small PR, breaking my earlier change into parts :)
@amitsela OK if I merge as-is and we move on to removing the DUMMY stuff afterwards?
Sure.

I'm for `local-runnable-on-service-tests` and `cluster-runnable-on-service-tests`. They should probably share the same base re-configuration of the `runnable-on-service-tests` execution, setting up deps to scan and exclusions.

The `cluster-runnable-on-service-tests` run has the complication that it requires credentials that will depend on who is running them, so you'll likely have to provide many options at the commandline, thus the savings of setting up the `--runner=XYZ` is minimal. But I generally like the idea of these both setting up some useful defaults so the mvn user only has to provide the necessary bits.
Thanks! Merged.

Eugene had a good suggestion: why not

Create.of(query) | ParDo.of(split query) | Reshard | ParDo.of(read from query)

Your code will probably be much simpler and we can let the dynamic work rebalancing happen on the GroupByKey inside of the reshard.
Done - removed getAppName in SparkStreaming options.
Interesting. Let me move that suggestion to the main RB where I implemented dyn rebalance. This change will be relevant either way since I am going to cleanup the mock stuff.

From Dan, 

```
Eugene had a good suggestion: why not

Create.of(query) | ParDo.of(split query) | Reshard | ParDo.of(read from query)

Your code will probably be much simpler and we can let the dynamic work rebalancing happen on the GroupByKey inside of the reshard.
```

Default values based upon which interface you invoke is generally not a good idea as the value will be "set" based upon which interface you invoke. Thus we should remove isStreaming() from SparkStreamingPipelineOptions.

Rebased again - same result.

The Mac build hangs while fetching deps. Note that the pre-merge build of [kennknowles/incubator-beam](https://travis-ci.org/kennknowles/incubator-beam/builds/147243614) passed.

So either it is infrastructural, nondeterministic, or there's some Mac-facing bug in mainline. Or some combination. Note that other PRs eventually get past this by repeatedly retrying. I'd rather not bother with that, but don't want to ignore a flaky issue either. Either way, not related to this change.
R: @dhalperi
LGTM
Waiting for Jenkins/Travis and will merge.
R: @kennknowles

@dhalperi @jkff  Nice idea, but once concern with the approach  is that GBK on Datastore Query is not possible since it cannot be deterministically encoded (It contains a proto Map). Create.of Source should itself be dynamic rebalancable right? Is there a way to avoid the GBK and just oversplit the queries and provide it to Create.of? (without having to split at pipeline construction time)?
No, you wouldn't use the Query as the key, but as the Value. See, for example, https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/Write.java#L266
LGTM

Just to confirm, this would mean that we no longer need to compute the estimated size and cannot leverage the 'desiredNumBytes' that runner would provide a source and instead rely on user provided numSplits or a default value.

The Google dependencies are actually under apache license right ? I would keep the license notice even if it's not required.

Will defer to you. They are under the apache license, but my reading of the Apache Members' response (linked in JIRA) was that we should not explicitly mention the Apache License as it's the assumed default.

+R: @jasonkuster

+1 for local-\* and cluster-*
One thing to consider - which cluster ? or to be accurate `resource-manager`. Spark can run it's own (Standalone Mode), use YARN or Mesos. According to the latest [survey](http://go.databricks.com/hubfs/DataBricks_Surveys_-_Content/Spark-Survey-2015-Infographic.pdf) by Databricks Standalone is in the lead (48%), with YARN tailing it (40%) while Mesos not too popular.
I'd vote for Standalone to test the most popular use case while avoiding the additional complexity of maintaining YARN on this cluster.
LGTM. Thanks!
Thanks Amit!

That is correct. Here's my proposal for the splitting ParDo:
- There is an option on the read to set the number of splits, which is used by default.
- If that option is missing, get statistics and break the job into 64 MiB-sized splits, with a minimum of 12 splits. This is equivalent to `BoundedSource#splitIntoBundles` with desired chunk size of 64 MiB.
- For now, don't make the split size overridable.
